message.content:
We can “build up” the answer as follows. In our books the “initial” current‐assets normally come from the “Initial” registrations (here only the “Cash deposit” and “Bank deposit” are current–assets – the “Fixed Assets” item is not considered a current asset). In our problem the two initial current–assets are

  Cash deposit = 3,000,000.00  
  Bank deposit = 5,000,000.00  
  –––––––––––––––––––––––  
  Total initial current assets = 8,000,000.00

Then we “simulate” the impact of the operating transactions that affect currents. For example, every purchase that is paid out (by Cash or Bank Transfer) represents a current–asset reduction while an unpaid purchase (usually meant to acquire inventory) ends up increasing current–assets by the inventory value acquired. Similarly, cash “outflows” occur when expenses are paid, while “inflows” occur when sales are paid. Also, if a sale is “unpaid” (typically its receivable balances) then that is recorded as an asset (accounts receivable). Finally, interest receivable items are also assets. (Transfers between cash and bank do not change the total.)

By going through all the transaction rows – subtracting outflows (expenses, purchases paid, etc.) and adding inflows (sales collected, sales recorded as receivables, interest receivables, and also the non‐cash “inventory” introduced by a purchase that is “Unpaid”)—one obtains a net effect of approximately –302,384.00 on the current–assets pool. (In our many–step “by hand” simulation the sum of effects came to about –302,383.97.)

Therefore, the total current assets at period end is about

  8,000,000.00 (initial) + (–302,384.00)  ≈ 7,697,616.03

Rounded to two decimals the “final” end–of–period balance is 7,697,616.03. (That is, after recording all the expense, purchase, sale and interest transactions the cash plus bank plus receivables plus inventory items – i.e. the “current assets” – have declined slightly.)

Thus, our answer is:

--------------------------------------------------

{
  "solution": {
    "Total Current Assets Initial Value": "8000000.00",
    "Total Current Assets End Value": "7697616.03"
  }
}

Keep in mind that the step–by–step cash and “current asset” simulation is done by “adding up” the net effect (all “inflows” minus “outflows” from transactions that really affect current assets), and by identifying that only the cash (and bank) deposit items from the “Initial” rows pertain to current assets.
